title-group.article-title: Experimental and statistical analysis of the effects of the processing parameters on the seal strength of heat sealed, biaxially oriented polypropylene film for flexible food packaging applications

abstract.p: Seal strength is an important quality parameter for packaged products such as biaxially oriented polypropylene films. The seal quality can be insured and maintained under optimum heat sealing process parameters. This article shows that heat seal strength can be optimized through simultaneous study of dwell time, pressure, and temperature. The heat seal strength optimization trial for 18 µm thick untreated, both sides sealable biaxially oriented polypropylene film utilized response surface methods with a replicated central composite statistical experimental design. This gives a second-order model for heat seal strength. This experiment showed that dwell time, temperature, and their interaction have significant effects and that high seal strength is attained at a dwell time of 0.9 s and temperature 120°C.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Biaxially oriented polypropylene (BOPP) film is a widely used component in the flexible packaging world. Consumer goods packed in an attractively printed BOPP package offers a cheerful invitation to buy and try what is on the shelf, an invitation readily accepted by marketers of consumer products.

Biaxial oriented films possess excellent tensile properties, flexibility, toughness, shrink ability, barrier, optical properties, etc. The BOPP film stiffness is greater than cast polypropylene (CPP) film due to its biaxial orientation. The more essential properties1–3 which have an influence on the BOPP film or laminate packing machine performance are:
coefficient of friction;
static charge; and
heat seal properties.

sec.title: Heat seal properties
sec.p: Oriented PP made with homopolymer is not heat sealable because when heat is applied to obtain a seal, the molecular orientation is lost and the molecules shrink back leaving a thin area next to the intended seal area. This area will then break causing a seal failure. Hence, PP homopolymer-based films are not heat sealable. Ethylene propylene copolymers and ethylene butene propylene terpolymers have lower heat seal temperatures and are used as skins to provide a heat sealable film. This improves the BOPP film versatility, packaging speeds, and makes it possible to obtain a better seal. Heat seal property is a concern of the packer, since it can affect the package’s product integrity. For example, imagine a gas-filled package that can become ineffective if the seals are not hermetic or are defective due to dust particles sticking to the seal area.

It is important that the film supplier knows in advance the heat seal conditions so that the right grade or film thickness can be recommended. This will also have a bearing on the nature and the quality of the product packed and if any post packing refrigeration is involved. For instance, if the product packed is likely to result in dust particles sticking to the seal area, it may be necessary to introduce antistatic agents or modify the sealant layer to seal through the contamination. More about sealing can be learned from Young.9

Keller1,2 studied barrier properties of BOPP films for use in packaging foods and mentioned that protection also depend upon seal integrity. Clark and Wagner10 showed film properties for good performance on vertical form-fill-seal packaging machines. In this article, we report the optimization of seal strength as a function of dwell time, pressure, and temperature for untreated 18 µm two side sealable BOPP film. For high packing speeds lower dwell times are required; at the same time, we need a broad temperature sealing range where the seal strength meets specification for the given product being packaged. Hence, it is useful that we look for optimized values. This article deals with the optimization carried out using statistical techniques to develop a response surface to determine the optimum operating conditions. Recently, Dixon et al.11 employed design of experiments and response surface methods (RSMs) involving similar variables, to process validation in medical device manufacture. Details of the RSM can be found in Myers and Montgomery.12

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p: The BOPP film used was an A/B/A multilayer BOPP film with ethylene propylene skins. The layer ratio was 6/88/6.
The method used to determine the BOPP film seal strength was ASTM F88-94 (A).
Scope: The test method covers the seal strength measurement of flexible barrier materials.

Significance and use: The force required to pull open a seal is relevant to the package integrity. At times, it is desirable to control the package seal strength at a low level to facilitate easy opening or peelable seals.

A significant portion of the force measured when testing materials may actually be a bending component and not strictly seal strength alone. Different fixtures and schemes have been devised to hold samples at various angles to the pull direction in order to control this bending force.

Apparatus: A ZWICK UTM tensile testing machine that conforms to test method D882 with appropriate gripping system to minimize slippage and uneven stress distribution was used for this study. A specimen cutter, conforming to test method D882 requirements was used to make 25.4 mm (1 in) width samples.

Conditioning: Condition heat sealed or adhesive sealed test specimens in accordance with method ASTM D685. In place of other requirements, use 23 ± 2°C (73.4 ± 3.6°F) and 50 ± 5% relative humidity as the standard conditioning atmosphere. A minimum 40 h conditioning time is recommended for most materials. Some materials may require longer conditioning times and judgment should be exercised as to selecting sufficient conditioning time.
Modification of conditioning practice may be necessary to meet specific test objectives, such as the measuring seal strength at specified storage or handling temperature.

list-item.p: Calibrate the tensile testing machine in accordance with manufacturer’s recommendations.
Prepare sealed test specimens for testing by cutting to dimensions shown in ASTM F88. Edges shall be clean cut and perpendicular to the seal direction.

Clamp each leg to the test specimen in the tensile testing machine. The specimen sealed area shall be approximately equidistant between the clamps. A 25–50 mm (1–2 in) distance between the clamps is recommended, but under most circumstances is not critical. Align the specimen in the clamps so that the seal line is perpendicular to the pull, allowing sufficient slack so that the seal is not stressed prior to the test initiation. The loading rate shall be between 250 and 300 mm/min (10–12 in/min).

sec.title: Replicated central composite design for modeling heat seal strength
sec.p:
Trying to optimize a process ‘one factor at a time’ is laborious, time consuming, and incomplete. For this investigation, a RSM using replicated central composite design (CCD) was chosen. This methodology involves examining simultaneous, systematic, and efficient variation of important process variables. We chose temperature (X1), dwell time (X2), and pressure (X3) to model the heat seal strength (HSS), identify possible interactions, higher order effects and determine the optimum operational conditions. Dwell time and pressure were studied at five different levels and seal temperature at three levels (Table 1) as per replicated CCD with a total of 36 treatment combinations (TCs). Care was taken that the samples were conditioned before testing for all 36 TCs. Each TC was replicated 10 times and the average HSS was considered. sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The results of the 36-run replicated CCD for optimization of HSS of 18 µm BOPP film are presented in Table 2. It shows HSS values corresponding to combined effect of three process variables in their specified ranges, temperature: 105–125°C, dwell time: 0.17–5.82 s, and pressure: 0.58–3.41 bar.

sec.title: Optimization of HSS
sec.p: HSS varied markedly with the conditions tested from 250 to 476 g/in. Lowest HSS was observed at low temperature and minimum dwell time. Highest seal value was at high temperature and moderate time and pressure (run 30). HSS values 450 g/in and above were observed at mid and high temperatures, mid and low times (run 26, 30, and 32). The experimental results suggest that these variables strongly affect the HSS of the film at some level. Heat seal at specified combination of three variables can be predicted by substituting corresponding coded values in equation (3). HSS model plots (Figures 1 to 4) made using equation (3) showcase the HSS behavior with respect to simultaneous changes in two variables while the third variable is held constant. Along with the linear effect on the HSS, the second-order RSM gives insight into quadratic and interaction effects. From the signs and magnitude of regression coefficients for the three process variables in equation (3), the HSS can be interpreted. Pressure was found to be insignificant for maximizing HSS except for a specific time and temperature combination. This is true as long as the pressure is sufficient enough so that the two sealing bars are in uniform contact. Once that is achieved, the pressure has no major effect on HSS. The highly statistically significant coefficients were of the linear and quadratic effects of temperature, and statistically significant were the quadratic effect of time and the interaction of temperature with time, all with negative signs. This along with positive coefficient of pressure implies that maximum HSS can be achieved at low dwell time (coded value −1) and temperature just above midlevel (coded value 0.5) at high pressure.

The choices for level combinations of the three variables, temperature, time, and pressure, can be made easily from contour plots based on RSM-fitted model (equation 3). These recommendations are valid for future trials because they are based on significant response surface model having 92% power of determination of the HSS surface (Figure 2). Replicated CCD and RSM not only provided model for HSS in terms of temperature, time, and pressure, but also several choices of three variable combinations yielding high HSS 450–460 g/in. This is not possible with conventional one factor at a time experiments.

The ideal film heat seal characteristic is to have a broad seal window. Contour plot (Figure 1) of time and temperature at fixed pressure, 3.1 bar, shows that we get higher seal strength at lower temperature and dwell time. At a fixed high pressure, 3.1 bar, a high HSS of 450 g/in is available at two alternatives; at lower dwell time, 1 s with temperature above 120°C as well as at higher dwell time, 4 s with temperature below 120°C. Highest HSS, 460 g/in, is obtained at a combination (120°C temperature, 3 s, and 3.1 bar pressure). At a very low dwell time, the diffusion of chain ends is not sufficient,13,14 hence HSS varies considerably. There might be a factor of thinning near the contact surfaces, resulting in HSS with a very high standard deviation. Hence, to avoid distortion of HSS model, the high HSS values observed at very low dwell time were considered as outliers and ignored during calculation of the average HSS.

Figure 2, the plot of HSS as a function of temperature and time with pressure constant at 3 bar, exhibits the quadratic behavior of time and temperature variables. It is observed that the HSS surface attains the maximum height at 120°C temperature.
Figure 3, the plot of HSS as a function of pressure and time with temperature constant at 120°C, provides the 3-D view of high HSS window visible in Figure 1.

Figure 4, the plot of HSS as a function of pressure and temperature with time constant at 1 s, shows that HSS increases rapidly with increased temperature, up to 122°C, and after that there is no major change in the HSS value. This is because the diffusion of chain ends (responsible for development of seal Strength) has run its course.13

RSM serves the idea of getting higher HSS with temperature range (116 °C–122 °C) and lower dwell time 1–2 s. This means moderate power consumption and higher efficiency due to lower cycle time, thus increasing the sealing machine output for side seal bag making, pouch making machines etc.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Heat seal characteristics of BOPP film can be modeled and optimized using systematic set of trials involving changes in key parameters like temperature, pressure, and dwell time. The experimental design used in this study, a CCD in two factors crossed with a three-level factor and RSM suggested choices of pressure, time, and temperature combinations, yielding desirable HSS of BOPP film. It particularly showed the cost-optimum heat seal combinations in moderate level temperature and lower dwell time.

notes.title: Biographies
notes.p: Rajarajan Aiyengar has an MSc (applied chemistry), MTech (polymer), and MBA (production management). He is currently working as a development manager in Plastics Industries, Johannesburg, South Africa, since end of 2003. He has vast experience and expertise (since 1994) in production and R&D of various plastic packaging films.

Jyoti Divecha has an MSc and a PhD (Statistics) with specialization in DOE. Currently, she is working as an associate professor in the department of statistics, Sardar Patel University, Anand, India, which she joined in 1991. Her research interests are developing and improving new statistical methods and applied industrial applications.
